page.title: 04BIRDS ON THE WYE
page.content: Birds such as the dipper and grey wagtail are always present along the river although the former has decreased due to acidification of the Irfon and its tributaries. Most of the herons within a 20 mile radius of here come from the heronry at Cefndyrys. The kingfisher is a resident on the river but suffers badly in severe winters when the river freezes as in 1981 because, unlike the dipper which goes below the ice, the kingfisher is then unable to dive. The goosander first began to breed in Wales (at the Elan Valley) only some 10-15 years ago and is now widespread and some say reaching pest proportions. This fish-eating duck is sometimes blamed for the decline in fish numbers though this is unlikely for the fish decline predated the increase in goosanders, which usually nests in holes in trees.
